instruction: Rinse the jeerakasala rice 2–3 times until the water runs clear. Soak it in water for 30 minutes.
title: Soak Jeerakasala Rice

transcript_segments.text: Hello everyone, welcome to Home Cooking with me, Hema Subramanian. When it comes to biryanis, there are different varieties from different regions. Today, I'm going to share a very special biryani all the way from Kerala. This is from the Malabar region—Talasheri Chicken Biryani. It's made using small-grain Jeeraga Sala or Jeeraga Samba rice, also known as Kaima rice. There are a couple of steps involved, so let's get started and dive right into the recipe.

First, we’re going to prepare the garam masala powder. I'm going to add a bunch of whole spices: 4 cardamoms, 2 pieces of cinnamon, 5 cloves, 2 star anise, ½ teaspoon of whole peppercorns, 2 small pieces of nutmeg, 2 small pieces of mace, and 1 teaspoon of fennel seeds.

Also add 1 teaspoon of shahi jeera and 2 Kashmiri red chilies. Dry roast all the whole spices for about 2–3 minutes on a medium-low flame. You'll start to get a lovely aroma. Turn off the stove, transfer the spices to a plate, and let them cool completely. Once cooled, grind the spices into a fine powder.

Our garam masala is ready and we'll use this for the biryani. It’s always best to grind it fresh. Now, we're going to fry the onions. In a kadai, pour enough oil for deep-frying. Once the oil is hot, gently add in two large thinly sliced onions.

instruction: Heat oil in a pan. Add thinly sliced onions and shallow-fry on medium heat until golden brown. Remove and drain on paper towels.
title: Fry Onions for Garnishing

transcript_segments.text: Fried onions are very important for this recipe. Fry them until golden brown, then remove and set aside. For garnish, we’ll also use cashew nuts and raisins. I’ve taken about 1 cup of cashews. Fry them till golden brown, remove, and keep aside.

instruction: In the same or a separate pan, heat ghee and sauté cashews until golden. Add raisins and sauté until they puff up. Set aside for garnishing.
title: Sauté Cashews and Raisins

transcript_segments.text: Next, fry about ½ cup of golden raisins. Once done, remove and keep aside. Now we have all the garnish elements ready. Next, we’ll cook the chicken. Take a wide pan or kadai and add ¼ cup of ghee.

For this recipe, I’ve taken 4 medium-sized onions, thinly sliced. Sauté the onions till golden. Then add 1½ tablespoons of garlic paste, 1½ tablespoons of ginger paste, and 2 tablespoons of green chili paste.

instruction: In a bowl, mix chicken with a little salt and turmeric. Let it sit for about 10 minutes.
title: Marinate Chicken Lightly

transcript_segments.text: After sautéing for 2–3 minutes, add 1 kg of bone-in chicken. Cook for 5 minutes, ensuring the ginger, garlic, and chili paste coats the chicken well. Add ½ tsp of turmeric powder and 2 tsp of salt.

instruction: Heat oil in a heavy-bottomed pan. Add the marinated chicken and sear on high heat until the outside is lightly browned.
title: Sear the Chicken

transcript_segments.text: After sautéing for 2–3 minutes, add 1 kg of bone-in chicken. Cook for 5 minutes, ensuring the ginger, garlic, and chili paste coats the chicken well. Add ½ tsp of turmeric powder and 2 tsp of salt.

instruction: Lower the heat and add ginger-garlic paste. Sauté until raw smell disappears. Add green chilies and chopped tomatoes. Cook until tomatoes soften.
title: Add Aromatics and Tomatoes

transcript_segments.text: After sautéing for 2–3 minutes, add 1 kg of bone-in chicken. Cook for 5 minutes, ensuring the ginger, garlic, and chili paste coats the chicken well. Add ½ tsp of turmeric powder and 2 tsp of salt.

instruction: Mix in red chili powder, coriander powder, and garam masala. Stir well. Add yogurt and cook until the masala thickens and coats the chicken.
title: Add Spices and Yogurt

transcript_segments.text: We’re cooking the chicken on high flame. Now add the freshly ground garam masala. This will add a lot of flavor. Also add 3 medium-sized chopped tomatoes.
After 10 minutes, add ½ cup of whisked curd. Continue cooking the chicken on high flame and mix well. Reduce the flame to medium. Add a few mint and chopped coriander leaves. Mix everything together.
Add 2–3 handfuls of crushed fried onions to the chicken. Mix it well. This adds great flavor. Finally, add 2 tablespoons of thick coconut milk. This is optional but adds a lovely flavor.

The chicken masala is ready. Keep it aside. Now we’ll cook the rice. I’ve taken 2 cups of Jeeraga Samba rice, also called Jeeraga Shala or Kaima rice. This is a short-grain rice and ideal for this recipe, but basmati can be used if unavailable. Wash the rice well and soak it in water for 10 minutes.

instruction: Cover the pan and cook the chicken on low heat until tender and fully cooked. Stir occasionally to prevent burning.
title: Simmer Chicken Until Cooked

transcript_segments.text: The chicken masala is ready. Keep it aside. Now we’ll cook the rice. I’ve taken 2 cups of Jeeraga Samba rice, also called Jeeraga Shala or Kaima rice. This is a short-grain rice and ideal for this recipe, but basmati can be used if unavailable. Wash the rice well and soak it in water for 10 minutes.

instruction: In a separate large vessel, bring ample water to a boil. Add whole spices, salt, and a few drops of oil.
title: Boil Water with Whole Spices

transcript_segments.text: To cook the rice, take a deep pot and add 2 teaspoons of ghee. Add whole spices: cinnamon, cloves, cardamom, bay leaf, and star anise. For 2 cups of rice, I’ve used 3¼ cups of water (250 ml measure). Add 1 tsp salt, mix well, cover the pot, and bring the water to a boil.

instruction: Add the soaked rice to the boiling water. Cook until 90% done – the grains should be soft but still firm in the center. Drain and set aside.
title: Cook the Rice

transcript_segments.text: Once the water starts boiling, add the soaked rice. Cover and cook on medium-high flame until the rice is done. Once cooked, turn off the stove.

instruction: In a deep pot, spread the cooked chicken masala at the bottom. Layer half of the cooked rice on top.
title: Layer Chicken and Rice

transcript_segments.text: Now that everything is ready, we’ll start the dum cooking. Take a heavy-bottomed pot and begin layering. First, add all the chicken at the bottom and spread it evenly. Then add half of the cooked rice and spread it out. Drizzle 1 teaspoon of ghee.

instruction: Sprinkle half of the chopped mint, coriander, fried onions, and lemon juice over the rice layer.
title: Add Herbs and Garnishes

transcript_segments.text: Add chopped coriander and mint leaves, some fried onions, fried raisins, and fried cashew nuts.

For added flavor, sprinkle a little garam masala powder and some saffron water (saffron strands soaked in hot water). Add the rest of the rice and spread it out evenly. Press gently. Drizzle another teaspoon of ghee.

Top with chopped coriander, mint leaves, fried onions, raisins, and cashew nuts. Sprinkle a little more garam masala powder and the remaining saffron water. Cover the pot with foil or seal with dough made from wheat flour or maida. Place a plate on top.

instruction: Add the remaining rice as the second layer. Top with the rest of the mint, coriander, and fried onions.
title: Repeat Layering

transcript_segments.text: Top with chopped coriander, mint leaves, fried onions, raisins, and cashew nuts. Sprinkle a little more garam masala powder and the remaining saffron water. Cover the pot with foil or seal with dough made from wheat flour or maida. Place a plate on top.

instruction: Cover the pot with a tight lid or seal with dough. Place over very low heat and cook for 15–20 minutes to allow the flavors to meld.
title: Seal and Dum Cook

transcript_segments.text: Top with chopped coriander, mint leaves, fried onions, raisins, and cashew nuts. Sprinkle a little more garam masala powder and the remaining saffron water. Cover the pot with foil or seal with dough made from wheat flour or maida. Place a plate on top.

instruction: Let the biryani rest for 10 minutes after dum. This helps settle the layers and enhance flavor.
title: Rest Before Serving

transcript_segments.text: Heat a tawa and place the pot on it. Keep the flame on medium-low and cook on dum for 20 minutes. After 20 minutes, open the pot. The biryani looks amazing. Use a large spatula to scoop from the bottom and serve hot with raita.
This Talasheri Biryani is full of flavor—chicken, fried onions, golden raisins, and cashew nuts. It’s absolutely delicious. You must try it. Let me know how it turned out for you!
